poem:
Art from the Leftovers

In the gallery's quiet,  
strips of catalog pages lie—  
woven whispers of history,  
discarded dreams in plastic and lace.  
Bright threads of memory  
cross each other like ancient pathways,  
not trash but tapestry,  
a dialogue of what's been forgotten,  
brought into a new world  
by hands that remember,  
loom-threaded and alive.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "From plastic bags to shoelaces, the art in this California show is made entirely of trash As a young artist, Miguel Arzabe visited art shows around the US to learn from others’ work. But his biggest source of inspiration were the exhibit catalogues. Fascinated by the documents, he decided to make his own work out of the books themselves. He cut the pages into thin strips and wove them into a large, intricate Andean tapestry". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: From plastic bags to shoelaces, the art in this California show is made entirely of trash As a young artist, Miguel Arzabe visited art shows around the US to learn from others’ work. But his biggest source of inspiration were the exhibit catalogues. Fascinated by the documents, he decided to make his own work out of the books themselves. He cut the pages into thin strips and wove them into a large, intricate Andean tapestry
